title: AB 1233
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 8547.2 of the Government Code is amended to define "employee" as an individual appointed by the Governor or employed in a state agency, including employees of the California State University and individuals appointed by the Legislature to a state board or commission. This definition also includes employees of the Supreme Court, courts of appeal, superior courts, and the Administrative Office of the Courts. An "illegal order" refers to a directive that violates laws or poses a threat to health and safety. The definition of "improper governmental activity" includes activities by state agencies or employees that violate laws, regulations, or government policies, and involve corruption, malfeasance, bribery, fraud, or economic waste. The definition of "improper governmental activity" includes activities by state agencies or employees that violate laws, regulations, or government policies, and involve corruption, malfeasance, bribery, fraud, or economic waste. This definition also applies to activities by the University of California, the Supreme Court, courts of appeal, superior courts, and the Administrative Office of the Courts, or their employees, that meet the criteria of this subdivision. A "person" is defined as an individual, corporation, trust, association, state or local government, or an agency. A "protected disclosure" is a good faith communication revealing improper governmental activity or a condition threatening health or safety. This includes reporting to the California State Auditor's Office or the Commission on Judicial Performance. Section 8547.16 of the Government Code requires state agencies to publicly report any substantiated improper governmental activities from whistleblower complaints, if they have a separate investigation policy. This applies to the University of California, California State University, and other state agencies. The disclosure of public records under Section 8547.16 of the Government Code does not require the disclosure of records that are exempt under other state laws, such as the California Public Records Act.
